bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree
bibl.series: National Museum of Canada, Bulletin no. 60, Anthropological Series, no. 11

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

seg.note: LB: When I asked Sakewew to tell me a last story, he said, {nimêstâtayôhkênasinin}: “I have run entirely out of sacred stories.” (Initial stem: {mêst-}: “exhaust”; medial {-âtayôhkanê-}, formed from the noun {âtayôhkan}: “prehistoric spirit-animal,” with post-medial {-ê-}; Plains Cree in this way freely forms a medial from any noun; compound final {-hsin}, consisting of pre-final {-ht-}: “come down, fall, lie” and animate intransitive verb final {-in}.) At last he produced this story, for which he perhaps delved deep into his memory, since it contains details about the contests of spirit-animals, as well as a number of unusual words.

p.seg: kîtahtawê wîkiwak ayîsiyiniwak , nîso okimâwak , pêyak macihkiwis ohtâwiya . Once upon a time some people dwelt in a place, and there were two chiefs, and one of them was Silly-Fellow's father. LB on {macihkiwis}: In this tale the position of this person is much like that of Wisahketchahk. On Star-Blanket Reserve one of my informants identified the two.
kîtahtawê awâsisak mihcêt sôsimêwak . Then at one time many of the children played at throwing snow-darts.

mahtih kakwêciyawêhitotâk ôma kâ-sôsimêyahk kahkiyaw , mahtih awîna nêhtâ-sôsimêt , awîna wâhyaw kê-pahkisiniyit , itwêw pêyak awâsis ôhkoma êw-ôhpikihikot . “Let us all try to outdo each other throwing snow-darts, and see who is the best at it, whose snow-dart lands farthest away,” said one child, who was being brought up by his grandmother.
êkosi sôsimêwak . So they threw their snow-darts.
êkwah ati-otinêwak sôsimâna . Then they went and picked up their snow-darts one after the other, as they came to them.
piyis pêyak osôsimâna ayîsisiniyiwa kônihk . At last only one boy's snow-dart was left lying on the snow.
pimitisahwêwak . They went after it.
êkâ wiya awiyak nôhtaw kita-kîwêw ! itwêw . [no translation]

êkwah piyisk ê-sakâyik êkotah ati-sêskipayiyiwa , ê-mitihtâcik ôhi sôsimâna , ê-paskwâyik êkotah wâhyaw , ê-sakâyik êkotê ispisiyiwa . At last they found it had gone into a wood. As they followed the track of that snow-dart, across a far stretch of prairie there, into the woods it had sped.
kîtahtawê êw-otâkosiniyik , awîn ôma , kî-mihtiskâyiw . Presently, as evening came on, they were deep in the woods. LB on {kî-mihtiskâyiw}: Unknown word; translation a guess.
kwayask ômis îsi cimasoyiwa osôsimâna . there, standing straight upright in the snow, like this, was the boy's snow-dart.
êkoyikohk yôtiniyiw ; misponiyiw . Just then the wind began to blow; it snowed.

seg.gloss: “Let us stay here.
We might freeze.
Let us set up a shelter; let us build a hut of wood.
Some of you are to gather grasses.

p.seg: misîhtâk kîkinaw , itwêw . Make our hut big,” he said.
êkosi osîhtâwak . Accordingly, they built it.
piyisk êh-tipiskâyik , kîsihtâwak . At last, when night came, they had finished it.
ê-wâpaniyik , kêyâpic mistahi mâyi-kîsikâyiw . The next morning it was still very stormy weather.

seg.gloss: “Let us not go home.

p.seg:
ka-kawacinânaw , itwêw ;
nikohtêk . We should freeze,” he said; “Gather firewood.

seg.gloss: And here by the door, dig away the snow.

p.seg: pêsîhkok kisôsimâniwâwak kahkiyaw , itwêw . All of you bring me your snow-darts,” he said.
miyâw . They were given to him.
kahkiyaw êkwah wîskwâhtêmihk cimahêw kahkiyaw sôsimâna . Then he stuck all the snow-darts on end into the floor, opposite the doorway.
êkwah kîksêpa wayawîw , êh-otinât kahkiyaw sôsimâna . Then, early in the morning, he went out, taking all the snow-darts.
nikamôw . He sang.
niyâk ! mâcîk ! itwêw awa , sôsimâna kâ-kîh-itisahomiht , kâ-kîh-pimitisahomiht . “Be off! Hunt!” he sang whose snow-dart had been followed to that place, had been pursued across the land.
êkosi âhci piko mâyi-kîsikâyiw . The storm kept on.

êkwah êw-otâkosiniyik ,
kahkiyaw pîhtokêk . Then, in the evening, “All of you indoors.
ôtah tawayâk iskwâhtêmihk mîna wiskwâhtêmihk , itwêw . Form two lines from the doorway to the opposite wall,” he ordered.
piyis êkosi tôtamwak . Soon they had done this.
kîtahtawê awa kâ-kîh-mitihtimiht osôsimâna êwako kâ-pîhtokêkociniyit osôsimâna . Then presently the snow-dart of him whose snow-dart had been tracked, came flying into the hut.
ê-kîh-itaskôtoyit osôsimâniwâwa , êkos îsi itaskôtoyiwa . in the order in which their snow-darts had gone, in that order they now came, one following the other.
kahkiyaw mihkôwiyiwa sôsimâna . All the snow-darts were stained with blood.
êkâya wayawîk ! itwêw . “Do not go out of the house!” he said.
kêtahtawê kâ-pah-pitihkohtiniyik kîkwa . Presently some things were falling with a repeated thud.

ê-k-îsi-pitihkohtiniyik kêkwah ,
êh hâw , êkwah wayawîk ! itwêw awa kâ-kîh-mitihtimiht osôsimâna . When those things had fallen with a thud, “There, now go out!” said he whose snow-dart had been tracked.
êkosi wayawîwak . Then they went out.

awin ôhi , nanâtohk pisiskiwah , okwâskwêpayihôsah , nanâtohk êhtasiyit pisiskiwah , ôki êh-minahocik sôsimânak , êwakonik êy-âpohtêcik , osâm ê-manitôwit awa osôsimâna kâ-mitihtimiht . What was there, but all kinds of game-animals, jumping deer, all the game-animals there are? For these snow-darts had killed game, and it was they were supplying meat, so much of a manitou person was he whose snow-darts had been tracked.

ômis itêyihtam :
ôki awâsisak ta-wani-kiskisiwak . thus he thought: “Let these children forget.
wîkiwâhk namoya ta-pikiskâtamwak ! itêyihtam . Let them not get homesick!” he thought.
tâpwê êkosih ispayiyiw . Really, it was so.
hâw , osîhtâk têsipicikanah kiyâm mihcêt ! itwêw . “Come, set up a great many drying frames!” he said.
êkosi tôtamwak ôki awâsisak . Those children did as he had bidden.
ê-tipiskâyik , âsay mîna ntomêw sôsimâna . At dark, again he asked for the snow-darts.

seg.q: êkâ wiya êkwah mêtawâkêk ôki sôsimânak .
seg.gloss: “Do not now play with these snow-darts.
Work.
Set up drying frames everywhere.

p.seg: ôtah akotâk kâhkêwakwah pîhcâyihk , itwêw . Hang up the dried meat indoors here,” he ordered.
êkosi tôtamiyiwa ôhi awâsisah . The children did as he said.

mayaw êh-wâpaniyik , âsay mîna nikamôw kîksêpâ , ê-sôsimât ,
mâcîk ! êh-itât sôsimâna . As soon as day broke, early in the morning again he sang, as he flung the snow-darts, bidding the snow-darts “Hunt!”

êy-otâkosiniyik ,
pîhtokêk kahkiyaw ! tawâyâk iskwâhtêmihk wiskwâhtêmihk mina ! itwêw . At nightfall, “Come inside, all of you! Form two lines from the door to the opposite wall!” he ordered.
êkosi tôtamwak . They did so.
âsay mîna pîhtokêkocinwak sôsimânak . Again the snow-darts came flying into the house.
âsay mîna âpohtêwak . Again they had supplied meat.
êkoyikohk âstê-kîsikâyiw . By this time the day was done.
êkoyikohk môcikêyihtamwak awâsisak , êh-mîcisocik . The children were happy, because they could eat.
êkosi itahkamikisiw ; pêyakwaniyiw êh-tôtahk . That was the way he managed things; it was always the same thing that he did.

piyisk ôma kâ-misi-sakâyik , êwakô wâsakâm akotêyiwa wiyâsah , nanâtohk mîciwinah , wiyawâw êh-atoskêcik . In time, all over that large grove pieces of meat were hanging, all kind of food supplies, as a result of their work.
mistahi mîsihtâwak . They had a big store of meat.

kîtahtawê awa macihkiwis kîksêpâ kâ-wayawît , ê-ntawi-sikit , êkotê êw-ohtiniyik , kâ-pê-paswêmâkwaniyik . Then at one time, when this Silly-Fellow had gone out in the morning, [no translation], from the direction whence the wind was blowing there came the smell of fat meat.
nôsôskam , ê-pasot , ê-paswêmâkasikêt . He set out in the direction of the scent, following the smell of fat meat.
kîksêpâ kisiwâk itêyihtam , pêyâhtik pimohtêw . In the early morning he thought it was near. [sic] He walked slowly.
ôma kâ-mahkâskwêyâyik êh-otihtahk , âsay otâkosiniyiw . When he reached that big wood, it was already evening.
kêyâpic paskwâyiw . Again he came to open country.
wayacâwiw . He broke into a run.
tahki paskwêmâkwaniyiw . All the while he smelled the scent of fat meat.
mitoni êh-otâkosiniyik , takohtêw . When it was well on toward dark, he got there.

seg.gloss: “Oho, our elder brother has come! Give him something to eat.

p.seg: nohtêhkatêw , itwêw awa sôsimânah kâ-kîh-mitihtimiht . He is hungry,” said he whose snow-dart had been tracked.
êkosi kapê-tipisk mîcisôw ; nôhtêhkatêw ayisk . Then he ate all night; for he was hungry.

êkwah awa k-âtoskahât sôsimâna êwako ômis îtwêw :
mahtih ta-mâyi-kîsikâw , êkâ ta-kîwêt awa nistês , êkâ kit-âcimot ! itwêw . Then the one who made the snow-darts work said, “Let there be stormy weather, so that this big brother of mine may not go home and tell what he has seen!” he said.
tâpwê êh-wâpaniyik , mâyi-kîsikâyiw . Really, the next morning, there was stormy weather.

êkosih ômisih itwêw :
mâcîk ! itêw sôsimânah . Then he spoke thus: “Hunt!” he said to the snow-darts.
êkosi tôtamwak . They did so.
kitâpamêw awa macihkiwis . Silly-Fellow watched them.

tâpwê pîhtokêpayiyiwa sôsimâna , kontah k-ôyâtamiyit awâsisah , êh-miywêyihtamiyit , êh-wiyinihtâkêyit . Really, the snow-darts came flying into the house, and boys cheered loudly with joy, and set about cleaning the game. LB on {k-ôyâtamiyit}: Unknown word; translation a guess.
êkosi kitâpamêw . He watched them.

seg.gloss: “Oh, little brothers, let me stay with you.

p.seg: osâm ninôhtêhkatân itêh k-ôhtohtêyân , êkâ awiyak ê-kîh-minahot , êh-nôhtêhkatêhk , pikoh êh-mêtawêhk , êkos êy-isi-mîcisohk , itwêw . I go hungry too much in the place whence I come, because no one there can kill any game, and all go hungry and eat only as one eats after a contest,” he said. LB: That is, the two chiefs, in person or by proxy, would engage in contests of magic power, each setting as stakes an agreed number of his followers, to be killed and eaten by the other side, in case of defeat.

seg.gloss: “Oh, big brother, we could not refuse you.

p.seg: osâm nam âwiyak kêhtê-âyiwiw ôtah ; pisisik awâsisak , itwêw awa sôsimânah k-âtoskahât . Especially as there is no older person here, but only children,” said he who made the snow-darts work.
pêyakwan êh-tôtahk . He did always the same thing.

kîtahtawê ê-wayawît kîksêpâ ,
mistahi mîsihtâwak ôki kâ-kîh-wanihihcik awâsisak , itêyihtam , êh-wiyinot ,
nika-kîwân . Then, early one morning, as he went out of the house, “A great supply of food have these children who have been lost,” he thought, and, because he had got fat now, “I shall go home.
nka-ntaw-âcimon , êh-itêyihtahk . I shall go tell what I have seen,” thought he.
tkîwêw . He went home. CHECK, HCW: probably typo.
êkosi kîwêpahtâw . He ran for home.

cîkih wîkiwâhk êh-ihtât ,
hâw , mahtih nistês kâ-kîwêt ,
nka-ntaw-âcimon , k-êtêyihtahk , ta-wani-kiskisiw ! namoya kit-âcimôw ! itêyiham awa sôsimânah kâ-kîh-mitihtimiht . When he had got near their dwelling-place, “Now then, let my big brother who is going home thinking, “I shall go tell what I have seen,” let him lose his memory! Let him not tell!” thought he whose snow-dart had been tracked.
wani-kiskisiw awa macihkiwis . That Silly-Fellow lost his memory.
ôhtâwiya wîkiyihk êh-pîhtokêt , konta pikw îsi ay-itwêw . As he entered his father's dwelling, he said all kinds of disconnected things.
êkosi namoya . So nothing came of it.

kîtahtawê mina êh-kawâhkatosot , êkâ kêkway êh-mîcit , êkosi kîksêpâ ê-ntawi-sikit , kâ-pê-paswêmâkwaniyik . After a time, when he was again starved lean, for he had nothing to eat, [no translation] there came the odour of fat meat.

seg.gloss: “That is the boys storing up food.

p.seg: nka-ntawi-mîcison , itêyihtam . I shall go there and eat,” he thought.
namwâc wîh-wâyônîw . He did not even think of going back.
namoya nôhtê-wîhtam , iyâyaw êh-nôhtêhkatêt . He did not want to tell about it, but thought only of his hunger.
sipwêhtêw . He started out.
êh-otâkosiniyik takosin . Towards nightfall he got there.

seg.gloss: “Here comes our big brother again.

p.seg: asamihk ; ta-mîcisôw , itwêw . Give him something to eat; let him eat,” said he.
êkosi tâpwê asamâw . So he was fed.
hâw , ôtah ka-wa-wîcêtinâwâw , nisîmitik , itwêw . “Now, let me stay here with you, my little brothers,” he said.
êkwah mistahi ayâwak mîciwin ôki awâsisak kê-kîh-wanihihcik . By this time, much food had those children who had been lost.

êkosi iyikohk mînah êh-wiyinot , êkoyikohk mînah ,
nka-ntaw-âcimon , itêyihtam . Then, when he had again got fat, again he thought, “Let me go tell what I have seen.”
êkosi kîwêw . So he went home.

mitonih cîki wîkiwâhk êh-ihtât ,
mahtih ta-wani-kiskisiw awa nistês kâ-wîh-âcimot ! itêyihtam . When he had got very near their dwelling-place, “Let my big brother lose his memory, who is going to tell what he has seen!” thought he.
tâpwê wani-kiskisiw . Really, he lost his memory.
kêkwâkanihk ôma ê-kîh-nâtamân ? itêyihtam . “What on earth was I going after?” he thought. LB on {kêkwânanihk}: Unknown word (or phrase?).
êkosi ay-ayâw mîn êkotah . So then he stayed there again.
kîtahtawê mîna êh-nôhtêhkatêt , êh-wayawît , mina kâ-pasot , êh-paswêmâkwaniyik . After a time, when again he was going hungry, as he stepped out of the tent, again he smelled the odour of fat meat.
nicawâc sipwêpahtâw . Off he ran; what else was there to do?
âsay mîna ntawi-takosin . Again he reached the place.
nisîmitik , namoy êkwah kiwîh-ohci-nakatitinâwâw , itwêw awa . “Little brothers, this time I shall not leave you any more,” he said.
ay-ayâw êkotah . He stayed there.
iyikohk mîna êh-wiyinot , kîwêw . When he had got fat again, he went home.
namoy êkwah nika-wani-kiskisin ; awâsisak mîsihtâwak , itwêw âskaw . “This time I will not forget: the boys have a supply of meat,” he said at intervals.

mwêhci ê-wîh-yôhtênahk wîkiwâw ,
awâsisak ! itwêw ; wani-kiskisiw . Just as he was about to open the door-flap of their tipi, “The boys!” he said; he had forgotten.
êkos îsi ay-ayâw ôhtâwiya wîkiyihk . So then he stayed in his father's tipi.

kîtahtawê mîna êh-kawâhkatosot , mîna kîksâpâ êh-wayawît , kêyâpic pê-paswêmâkwaniyiw . After a time, when he was again lean with hunger, as he stepped out of doors in the morning, again there came the scent of fat meats.
êwakonik nisîmak kâ-mîsihtâcik ! itêyihtam . “That is my little brothers laying up a store of meat!” he thought.
sôskwâc sipwêpahtâw . At once, off he ran.
êy-otâkosiniyik , takopahtâw . Towards nightfall, he got there, on the run.
êkosi ay-ayâw mîn êkotê . So then he again stayed there.

seg.q: tânisi awa êsiyîhkâsot , awa kâ-tipêyimiyêk , awa nisîm ?
seg.gloss: “What is his name, his who directs you, this little brother's [sic] of mine?”

seg.q:
ôtah wiya wâh-wîhiyêkoh ,
k-ôsôsimânisiw , kik-êsiyîhkâsinâwâw ,
kîh-itwêw .
seg.gloss: “‘When here you wish to call me by hame, “Little Snow-Dart,” you will call me’ he has said.

p.seg: êkosi nama wîhkâc niwîhânân , itik awâsisah . And so we never call him by his name,” the boys told him.

iyikoh mîna êh-wiyinot ,
hâ , nisîm , tânis ôma êsiyîhkâsoyan ? itêw . When he was fat again, “Well, little brother, what is your name, really?” he asked him.

seg.q:
ô , nistêsê , oki mânah kâ-wîcêwakik ,
k-ôsôsimânisiw , nitisiyêhkâtikwak .
seg.gloss: “Why, big brother, they who are with me here call me ‘Little Snow-Dart.’
That is what they always say.”

p.seg:
êkwah kîksêpâ kâ-kîwêt ,
nisîm k-ôsôsimânisiw mîsihtâw , itwêw âskaw . Then, in the morning, when he went home, “My brother Little Snow-Dart has a store of meat,” he said at intervals.

wîkiwâhk ê-takosihk ,
namoy êkwah ta-wani-kiskisiw ; kiyâm kitâcimôw nistês ! itêyihtam . When he arrived at their dwelling-place, “Now let him not forget; let my big brother tell what he has seen!” thought he.

êkos êh-pîhtokêt wîkiwâhk ,
nisîm mîsihtâw osôsimânisiw . So, when he entered their tipi, “My brother, Little Snow-Dart, has a store of meat.
nikêh-otinâw , êh-tâpâhkômak , nôhtâh , itêw ôhtâwiyah ; I have taken him up, adopted him, father,” he told his father;

seg.q: ôtah awa nôhkominân kâ-wîkit , êwako ôsisima kâ-mîsihtâyit .
seg.gloss: “This grandmother of ours who lives right here, it is her grandson has the store of meat.

p.seg: mâka nnitawi-wîhtamôwâw nôhkom , itwêw ; But I am going to tell my grandmother about it,” he said;

seg.gloss: “‘Tomorrow let our father move his camp here, and my grandmother, too.
seg.note: LB on {kita-pê-piciw}: A preverb particle, such as {pêh}: “hither” is freely added to any verb, e.g., {pêhitohtêw}: “he walks hither.” An initial stem, such as {pê-}: “hither” is never added to a word, but appears only before non-initial elements, as in {pêpahtâw}: “he runs hither,” where {-pahtâ-}: “run” is an element that never occurs in word-initial. Thus: particle: initial stem: {papêh} {papâm-}: “around, about” {isih} {it-}: “thither, thus” {ohcih, ôh} {oht-}: “thence, therefore” and many others. There is overlapping of two kinds. In central Algonquian certain initials and non-initial stems are alike (except for the difference implied by these names), e.g. Cree {pici-} and {-pici-}: “move camp,” whence {pêh-piciw} and {pêpiciw}: “he moves camp hither,” probably with some difference of meaning. The other kind of overlapping is peculiar to Cree, and probably due to phonetic alterations which shifted the boundary between {t} (which occurs at the end of many initial stems) and {c} (which occurs as the penult of many particles). Thus {pêcâstam-}: “facing hither,” as, e.g. in {pêcâsamohtêw}: “he walks facing hither” looks as though it contained a preverb particle *{pêcih}: “hither,” which otherwise is unknown in Plains Cree, or else an initial stem {pêc-}, a form unparalleled in Cree and in the related languages. The initial stem here was really *{pêt-}; Cree {pêcâstam-} is a phonetic or analogic modification of *{pêcâstam-}, cf. Menomini {pîtâ'namôhnew}: “he walks facing hither.” Similarly Cree {mistatim}: “horse” for *{mistastim} (or *{misc-astim}, or *{mis-astim}). Cf. Introduction.

p.seg: kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniwak ta-pê-piciwak , êh-itwêt nisîm k-ôsôsimânisiw , itêw ôhtâwiya . All the people are to move camp to this place,” says my brother, Little Snow-Dart,” he told his father.
êkosi tâpwê miywêyihtam aw ôkimâw , ê-ntohkêmoyit awâsisah . Truly, then, this chief was glad that the boys were inviting people.
kitawâsimisiwâwak kâ-kîh-wanihâyêkok kinitawêyimikowâwak , êh-mîsihtâcik , itwêw . “Your boys whom you have lost want you to come to them, because they have got a store of meat.” he said.
tâpwê kîksêpâ kahkiyaw piciwak , awa kotak mîn ôkimâw . So, in the morning, they all moved camp, including that other chief.
tâpwê mitonih êw-otâkosiniyik tako-piciwak . Late in the evening they arrived with their camps.
ncawâc ay-âpihtaw ayâwak ôhi wiyâsah . They had to share the meat half and half.

seg.q: kotak aw okimâw nama nântaw kik-êtohtânâwâw .
seg.gloss: “You are not to go anywhere in the precinct of this other chief.
You are not to go back to your homes.
You are to stay here in our house.

seg.q: niya nôhkom âskaw wîkihk nik-âpin , âskaw kistêsinaw wîkiwâhk .
seg.gloss: As for me, some of the time I shall stay in my grandmother's tent, and some of the time in my big brother's.

p.seg: êkosi kika-tôtênânaw , itwêw . That is the way we shall do,” he commanded.
êkwah pêyak mostos otakisiyah ê-kî-pâsahkik , êyakonih ntawi-miyêw ôhkomah . Then he went and gave his grandmother the entrails of a buffalo, which they had dried.

seg.gloss: “Grandmother, take care of these.

p.seg: êkâya wîhkâc otinah , itwêw . Do not ever take them,” he said.
êkwah kiyipa atih-kitânawêwak . Then, soon they had eaten up all the food.
ômis itwêw nâha kotak okimâw ; - Thus spoke that other chief -
êh-otâkosiniyik pêh-tah-tahkiskamwân wîkiwâw macihkiwis : at nightfall there came a kicking at the tipi of Silly-Fellow and his family:
êkwah mina kimêtawânânaw , nê-mitanaw kit-êhtasihk , itwêw êwak âna okimâw . “Now again we shall engage in a contest, to the number of forty,” said that other chief.
ôhtâwiya tapahtiskwêyiyiwa . His father bowed his head.

êkosi ,
tânisi , nistêsê , êy-isi-mêtawêhk ? Then, “In what way, big brother, is it that they contend?”

seg.gloss: “Oh, little brother, it is a contest on the ice.

p.seg: êkosi mâna kôhtâwiyinaw pikoh ê-nâ-nakâhtwât , itâw . And in this our father is always defeated,” he was told. LB on {ê-nâ-nakâhtwât}: Freely formed secondary derivative {nakâhtwâw}: “he stops people,” from a freely formable *{nakâhêw}, *{nakâhtâw}: “he stops him, it”; cf. {sâkohêw}, {sâkohtâw}: “he overcomes him, it” and {sâkohtwâw}: “he overcomes people.” Yet the actual translation is a guess.

hâh , nistêsê , tahtwâw kê-mêtawêhk , ta-nâh-nîsinâniwiw , itwêw awa kâ-kîh-mîsihtât . “Now then, big brother, in each contest let there be two instead of one on a side,” said he who had made the supply of meat.
kitah-nâ-nîsinâniwiw , itwêw nisîm , itêw ôhi . “‘There are to be two on a side,’ says my brother,” he told those others.
êkw ê-wâpaniyik , itohtêwak . Then, the next morning, they went to the place.
êkwah awa k-ôsôsimânisiw itohtêw . Little Snow-Dart went there, too.
pôti ayênânêw-mitanaw mâmawow ihtasiwak wiyawâw awa êh-âstwâtocik . He saw that eighty was the number of them, all together, whom they and the other were staking.

êkos êw-otihtahkik miskwamîhk , êkwah awa kâ-manitôwit kotak okimâw oskinîkîma , êwakoni nêtê si-kwâskohtiyiwa miskwâmîhk . Then, when they had come to the ice, the servant of that other chief, who had spirit power, leaped out upon the ice.

pôtih nikikwah kâ-kôkiyit miskwamîhk , êkwah nêtê tâwakâm êkotê kâ-môskipêyit . And behold, there was an otter diving into the ice, and there, out in the middle of the lake, there it came bobbing forth.
kâwih kôkiyiwa , êkwah ôtah itah kâ-kîh-ohci-kôkiyit , êkotah wêh-pê-pasikôyit ayîsiyiniwah . Again it dived, and back here, whence it first had dived, he rose to his feet in human form.

êkwah macihkiwis ohtâwiya êsi-kwâskohtiyit , pôt âwa sâkwês kôkîw itah kâ-kîw-ohci-kôkiyit nikikwah . Then, when Silly-Fellow's father leaped forth, there, a mink was diving where the otter had dived in.
itêh kâ-kîh-pêkopêyit , êkotê pêkopêw awa macihkiwis ohtâwiya . Where the other had come to the surface, there Silly-Fellow's father came up.
âsay mîna kâw-ohci-kôkiyit , êkotah ohci pê-pasikôyiwa ohtâwiya . Then, again, where the other had dived in, Silly-Fellow's father rose to his feet.

sâkowêw macihkiwis ,
nâh-nam âwiyak ? êh-itwêt . Silly-Fellow began to cheer, crying, “They are done for!”

seg.gloss: “No! You have been defeated.

p.seg:
kont îtah miskwamiyah kîh-pikwâskawât kôhtâwiy ,
nâh-nam âwiyak ! ka-kîh-itwâhtânaw ! itâw ; If your father had broken through the ice, no matter where, then we could have cried, ‘They are done for!’” he was told;
mâka tâpi-pimotam , itâw . “But he has merely followed the other's lead,” he was told. LB on {tâpi-pimotam}: The term {pimotam}: “he shoots (it)” is used for taking one's turn in any kind of contest.
êkwah awa kotak misiwê cah-câhkasinahikâsôw . The second contestant of the other side was speckled all over his body.
kawipayihôw , kontah êh-ati-kâh-kwêtipipayihot êyîni-kinosêw . He threw himself to the ground, and there was a muskalonge flopping about.
namwâc pisoskawêw miskwamiyah . It did not even touch the ice as it went.

nêtêh tâwakâm mîna êkotê êh-wayawît , êkotêh ohci pa-pêcâstamohtêw awa ayîsiyiniw kâ-kinosêwit . Then, when it came forth yonder at the centre of the expanse, from there came walking in human form that man who had been a fish.
êkwah awa k-ôsôsimânisiw nikamôw , êh-pâkâskwâhikêt osôsimânah . Then Little Snow-Dart changed, pounding with his snow-dart as though on a drum.

seg.gloss: “The otter is beaten!”
seg.note: LB on {misinihâw}: Unknown word; translation a guess.

p.seg: êh-itotâmot , kawipayihôw : amisk . As he sang, he threw himself to the ground: a beaver. LB on {êh-itotâmot}: Unknown word; translation a guess.
amiskôwiw . He turned into a beaver.
pêkamahwâci miskwamiyah , anta misiwê kâ-ma-matwêskopayiyik . Whenever he struck the ice, everywhere crashing it would break.

pâh-pimitohtêw , ê-nikamot ,
nîkân ntamiskôwin ! êh-itwêt . He walked in different crosswise ways, singing, and, “First I am a beaver!” were his words.
kôkîw . He dived.
nêtê tâwakâm kîtahtawê miskwamiy kontah kâ-cimasot , miskwamiy êh-wayawîwêpiskawât . Suddenly over yonder, in the middle of the lake, the ice stood pell-mell on end, as he flung it aside in emerging.

kont êkwah sâkowêw macihkiwis , ôpispâskwatôwi-pakamâkan êh-tahkonahk . At this, Silly-Fellow cheered wildly, and laid hold of his knobbed war-club. LB on {opispâskwatôwi-pakamâkan}: If correctly recorded, probably some kind of reduplication of {piskw-}: “lump,” as in {piskwahcêw}: “it is lumpy land.”
kêhcinâhôwak êh-sâkôcihihcik . They saw beyond doubt that they were defeated.
hâh , paskiyâkêw k-ôsôsimânisiw . Oh, Little Snow-Dart had defeated the opponent.
hâw , êkwah êw-otâkosiniyik , kisiwâhtwâw macihkiwis ôhtâwiya . That evening Silly-Fellow's father was enviously hated.

seg.gloss: “Let the number be sixty tomorrow.

p.seg:
na-nâ-nîsinâniwiw
itwêw , itâw . ‘Let the contestants be in pairs,’ says he,” he was told.
êhag , itwê , nisîm , itwêw . “Say, ‘Yes,’ little brother,” said he.

âsay êkosi kîksêpâ ,
tânisi êy-isi-mêtawêhk , nistêsê ? itêw . Then, early in the morning, “What kind of contest is it, big brother,” he asked him.

seg.gloss: “One withy is to be shot.
seg.note: LB on {pêyak wanaskât}: I do not know whether {pêyak wanaskât} is one or two words, i.e. whether the independent word {wanaskât} is found in Cree or not.

p.seg: êyako mâna sôskwâc nipaskiyâkawinân , itwêw macihkiwis . In this we are always defeated at once,” said Silly-Fellow.
kîksêpâ itohtêwak . In the morning they went there.
hâ , tâpwê nîsosâpo-mitanaw ayîsiyiniwak ayâwak êkotah . Really, there were a hundred and twenty men there.
êkwah awa nîkân kâ-pimotahk nîsocihc kita-pataham ! itwêw awa k-ôsôsimânisiw . “Now let him who shoots first miss the mark by two fingers!” said Little Snow-Dart.
pôtih tâpwê êkoyikohk patahamiyiwa . Really, by even that much the other missed the mark.

ôhtâwiyah êkwah pêmotamiyit ,
cîki nîsocihc , apisîs ayiwâkêsîs ta-pataham awa ! itêw ohtâwiya . Then when his father shot, “Close to two fingers, by a tiny bit more, let this one miss it!” he said of his father.
tâpwê âsay macihkiwis sâkowâtâwak . Truly, already Silly-Fellow's side were being whooped at.
êkwah awa kotak âsay mîna pimotam ; min êwako kêkâc tâwaham . Then the second opponent shot at it; he too almost hit it.
êkwah awa osôsimânah isiwêpinêw . Then he flung his snow-dart at it.
sêmâk kont îtê itakociniyiwa . At once it went speeding in every direction through the air.
pîs kwaskipayiyiyiwa . At last it whirled round. LB on {kwaskipayiyiyiwa}: Probably an error of record; perhaps for {kwêsk-}: “twisting to one side.”
pôtih kwayask kâ-môskistamiyit osôsimâna ; tâwaham . Lo and behold, his snow-dart made straight for the mark; he struck it square.

ohtakocin awa sôsimân , konta kâ-sâkowêt macihkiwas , êh-ati-pakamahwât ôhi astwâkêwinah . Down fell the snow-dart, and wildly whooped Silly-Fellow, as he began to club, one after the other, those who had been set as stakes.

hâh , êw-otâkosiniyik ,
âh , ayênânêw-mitanaw êkwah kit-êtasinâniwiw , itâw . Then, in the evening, “Now, this time let the number be eighty,” he was told.

seg.gloss: “How is it to be this time, big brother?”
“Over the smooth place on the ice there will be a race.

p.seg: nama wîhkâc paskiyawâwak , itwêw . they are never beaten at this,” he said.

seg.gloss: “Oh, very well!”

p.seg: wiyâpaniyik , itohtêwak . The next morning they went there.
pôtih âsay ayâyiwa êkotê ; êkwah ay-isi-sipwêhtêwak . There, the others were there already; then they started.
ôhtâwiya awa k-ôsôsimânisiw akâmihk wâhyaw ohcipayiyiwa . Little Snow-Dart's father was coming a long ways off, from the far shore.

itê têkohtêcik ,
hâw , kimêtawâhtânaw ! kikakwê-nakatitohtânaw ! itâw macihkiwis ohtâwiya . When they got there, “Oho, do not forget we were to have a contest! Do not forget we were to race each other!” silly-Fellow's father was told.
kawipayihôw , nikikwah êh-ati-sôskopayihoyit . He flung himself down, and off went an otter, sliding over the smooth surface.
mêhkawikiyiwa . He went fast.
hâw , nôhtâh , pimitisahikêh ! itêw ohtâwiya . “Come, father, go in pursuit!” he said to his father.

êkwah ômis îtwêyiwa ohtâwiya :
nama nika-kê-atimâw , nikosê ; Then his father said, “I shall not be able to overtake him, my son;
nitaciwihik , itwêyiwa . he has far outdone me,” said he.
êh-kawipayihot , pôt âwa sâkwês . When he flung himself down, there was a mink.
wîst êyiwêhk sôskopayihôw . It, too, as well as it might, went gliding over the ice.

êkwah awa k-ôsôsimânisiw wîci-pakêsah êwakoh ,
oskac êh-pawâmiyân , atihkwasiniy nikîh-kitimâkêyimik ! itwêw , êh-kawipayihot . Then the opponent who was paired with Little Snow-Dart, said, “When first I dreamt, the elk-ball took pity on me!” and threw himself on the ground. LB on {atihkwasiniy}: Literally “elk-stone,” but what is it? {môsw-asiniy}, {môsasiniy}: “moose-stone” is a gun-bullet. CHECK wîci-pâkesah. HCW: yup.
kisîkocin aw âtihkwasiniy . Swiftly that elk-ball went speeding.

êkwah awa k-ôsôsimânisiw ,
oskac êh-pawâmiyân , âkwask kik-âpin . Then Little Snow-Dart said, “As first I dreamt, on ahead you will stay still.

âpihtaw miskwamîhk kika-têhkicêskiwakisinin ! itwêw ; Half-way across the ice you will flounder as though mired!” he said; LB on {kika-têhkicêskiwakisinin}: {têhk-} is unknown to me; perhaps an error of record for {tihtip-}: “turning over or round,” cf. below. The medial {-cêskiwak-} means “mud, sticky stuff.”
oskac êh-pawâmiyân , nêyâhtakâw nikî-kitimâkêyimikon ! itwêw . “When first I dreamt, the treetop took pity on me!” he said. LB on {nêyâhtakâw}: Translation a guess; cf. {nêyâw}: “promontory.”
tâpwê pimitisahwêw . Truly he went pursuing the other.
k-êspisakotêki môsasiniyah , êkoyikohk kik-êspisîn , nisôsimân ! itwêw . “As swiftly as speeds a bullet through the air, so swiftly will you speed, my snow-dart!” he said.
tâpwê êy-otihtahk opawâmôwin , awîn ôma , kiy-âkwaskîw . Truly, when he reached that which had befriended him in dreams, why, there he was in the lead.
pikiwah pasakoskiwah mistahi osêpiyiwa ôhtâwiya ; cîk êkotah at-âyâyiwa . In pitch, in sticky gum his father was badly stuck; close to that place the others were passing.
nôhtâh , micimîw otêh otahk ! êkosih itêw . “Father, hold fast here, at the rear!” he said to him.
nawaci-micimîw sôsimânihk , êh-atimât ôhi nikikwah . He seized hold of the snow-dart as it passed him, and overtook that otter.
kikakwê-nakatitohtânaw ! itêw . “Do not forget we were racing!” he said to it.
êyag ! âta wêy âni nitispisipayin ! itik . “Yes! Don't you see how fast I am going?” it answered him.
êkwah ôhi atihkwasiniyah . Then that elk-ball.
tihtipicêskiwakisin . It was floundering in something that held if stuck fast.
kikakwê-nakatitohtânaw ! itêw . “Do not forget we were racing!” he said to him.
êyag ! itâp anih nitispisipayin ! itêw . “Yes! Can't you see how fast I am going?” it said to him.
tâpwê nakasiwêwak macihkiwis ohtâwiya . Truly, Silly-Fellow's father and his partner were outstripping the others.
êkosi êkwah kisiwâhâwak ôki . This made the others angry.
hâw , êyâhtasihk êkwah ! itâwak . “Come, in full number now!” they were told. LB on {êyâhtasihk}: The first two syllables may be wrongly recorded.
nama ta-kîh-sâkohtwâcik . they could not possibly defeat the others.
êkwah namoya ka-tâpi-pimotênânaw ! itâwak . “And this time we shall not do as the other does!” they were told.
êkwah awa k-ôsôsimânisiw ntawi-ntomêw awâsisah . Then Little Snow-Dart went and called the boys.

seg.gloss: “Now, go help our grandmother.
They are to be very small;

p.seg: cîsawâtamok ôhi otakisiyah , itwêw . cut up those entrails,” he said.
êkwah wiyâpaniyik , sôskwâc ispiciwak kahkiyaw sisonê sâkahikanihk . Then, the next morning, at once they all went in a body to the edge of the lake.

êkwah ,
nisîm , kika-sâkohtwân cî ? itêw . Then, “Little brother, shall you win?” he asked him.

seg.gloss: “No.

p.seg: mâskôc osâm ayiwâk at-âyimaniyiwa , itâw awa macihkiwis . Doubtless the other is too formidable,” Silly-Fellow was told.
mistahih âyimêyihtam . He was very much distressed.
êkwah awa nîkân pimotam macihkiwis ohtâwiya . Then Silly-Fellow's father had the first turn.
kâ-wîci-pakêsiyit kâ-misikiticik sihkihpak êkotôwiw , pikw îtah êh-pikwâskâwât miskwamiyah ; His opponent was in the shape of a great diver-duck, crushing through the ice wherever it went;

êkwah awa macihkiwis ohtâwiya itôwahk k-âyôtôcikâtihcik êkotôwahk . and Silly-Fellow's father was one of those that are made merry over. LB on {k-âyôtôcikâtihcik}: The allusion is plainly to the hell-diver duck; the difficulty is that the present passage seems to imply a difference between the “diver-duck” ({sihkihp}) and “the one that is made merry over.”
êkwah kâwi itah wêh-pêkopêyici , êkotah ohci-kôkîw awa macihkiwis ohtâwiya . Then from wherever the other came to the surface, from there Silly-Fellow's father would emerge after his dive.
hâ , tâpwê paskiyawâwak ! itwêyiwa . “Ho, truly they are beaten!” said the others.
ayis tâpi-pimotam . For he was but following the other's lead.

êkwah awa k-ôsôsimânisiw wîci-pakêsah âsay mîn êyako nikamôw ,
nitamiskôwin niya ! êh-itwêyit . Then the opponent who was paired with Little Snow-Dart, he too began to sing, saying, “I am a beaver, I!”
mitonih misikitiw amisk . Very large was the beaver.
pêkamahahahki , osoy ohci misiwê mamatwêskopayiyiw . Whenever it struck anything with its tail, in all directions it went crashing.

êkosih asawâc itêh ohci kôkîw , konta mâna miskwamiyah kâ-sêhkwêpiyit , itêh piyêkopêyici . It dived from the other direction, and always the ice went breaking, wherever it came to the surface. LB on {kâ-sêhkwêpiyit}: Unknown word; perhaps an error of record.
kêtahtawê miton ôtah sisonê piyêkopêyit . Suddenly it came to the surface right there, very close to the shore.

ômis îtêw ostêsah mîn ôhi amiskwah :
iyikohk takosiniyâni , kika-mâtahpinatâwâwak , êkâ ayiwâk kîh-tôtamâni . Thus he spoke to his big brother and to that beaver: “When I arrive you may begin to slay them, in case I cannot surpass what has been done.

seg.gloss: Not before I arrive;

seg.q: misawâc nika-kiskêyihtên , awiyak nîkân kê-pakamahwât awiya .
seg.gloss: I shall be sure to know it, if anyone before that strike down the other.

p.seg: êkosi namoya kwayask kit-êspayiw , itwêw . If that is done, things will not go well,” he said.

nikamôw :
niyah niwâpamâkôwin ! itwêw , miskwamîhk êh-pakicît . He sang: “I am a white loon, I!” he sang, as he alighted on the ice. LB on {niwâpamâkôwin}: One expects {niwâpimâkôwin}; if the text is correct, it contains an archaic or pseudo-archaic medial stem {-amâkw-}: “loon”.
papâmohtêw miskwamîhk , kontah êh-pâ-pimitohtêt , piyisk k-âtih-sâsopêyit miskwamiyah . He walked about on the ice, crossing it in every direction, until at last water began to seep through the ice.
cêhkatahwâcih miskwamiyah , kontah misiwê kâ-ma-matwêskopayiyit . Whenever he struck the ice with his beak, on all hands it would move with crashing noise.
âhkami-kitow mâkwa . Unceasingly the loon gave its call.
piyisk waskitisik nipîwiyiw , êh-âhkami-kitot . At last the water stood on top of the ice, as he unceasingly gave his call.
pîsk yôtinipayâstaniyiw . At last a wind began to blow.
êkoyikohk sâkowêw macihkiwis . Then Silly-Fellow whooped.

seg.q: namoya wiyawâw nipiy osîhtâwak ! wiya nisîm nipiy osîhtâw !
seg.gloss: “It is not they are making the water to be! It is my brother is making the water to be!
But, ‘Not before I arrive,’ said my brother!
Two of them I shall pick out to eat, fat ones.

p.seg: ayis niya nisîm nkîh-otinâw , itwêw . For it was I adopted him as my little brother,” he cried.
kôkîw awa mâkwa , akâmihk nêtê kâh-matwê-kitot mâkwa , êkotê mina . The loon dived, and lo, yonder on the far shore a loon was giving its call, and over here another.
piyis mâ-mahkâskâw ôma sâkahikan . At last the lake ran to high waves.
piyis nama kêkway miskwamiy . At last the ice was gone.
kîtahtawê pê-kôkîw ôtah kisiwâk . Suddenly he bobbed up right close by.

piyêkopêt ,
hâw , âstamitik ! kahkiyaw êkâya awiyak nipahihk ! âstamitik ! itêw ; As he came to the surface of the water, “Now, then, all of you, come here! Let none of you slay anyone! Come here!” he ordered them;

seg.q: êkwah ôhi ocakisîsah tahtoh êh-pâpayihtâcik , ohpimêh kit-âti-nîpawiwak .
seg.gloss: “Now as many as cast up these bits of entrail, let them stand off to one side.” he ordered.

p.seg: tahtoh êkâ êh-pâpayihtâcik mîna êwakonik ohpimê ta-nîpawiwak , itwêw . And as many as do not cast them up, let them too stand to one side,” he ordered.
êkwah âtiht pâpayihtâwak . Then some of them threw them up.

seg.q: â , kiyîsâhkamikisit , tahtoh kâ-pâpayihtâyêk , mistikwah kik-ômîciwinâwâw , âtiht maskosiyah .
seg.gloss: “Now then, when the order of things is completed, as many of you as have cast it up, trees shall be your food, and grasses, of some.
seg.note: LB on {kiyîsâhkamikisit}: Probably read {hk} for the final {t}; I have so translated.

seg.gloss: For, ‘Go lay down a law!’ I was told.

seg.q:
kiya , nistêsê , ayîsiyiniwak nihtâwikitwâwi , ohpikitwâwi ,
pahkwacôw , kik-êsiyîhkâtikwak ;
seg.gloss: You, my brother, when mortal men grow forth and flourish, ‘Lynx,’ they will call you;
seg.note: LB on {pahkwacôw}: Allusions to the lynx may be introduced on my account.

seg.gloss: you will find your sustenance in the woods;
and so you, my brother, have found your place.

seg.q:
êkwah kiya , nôhtâh ,
sâkwês , kik-êsiyîhkâtik ayîsiyiniw ;
seg.gloss: And you, my father, ‘Mink,’ mortal man will call you;
by the water you will have your domain;

seg.q: mâka nanâtohk kêkway kika-mîcin , kinêpikosak wiyâs ;
seg.gloss: but all kinds of things you will eat, the flesh of little snakes;
from whatever creature has flesh you will get your life.
So now in different directions, into the form of different animals you will all go.
When mortal men come into being, they will overcome you all.
As for me, ‘Great White Loon,’ I shall be called.
But not here shall I stay.

p.seg: kâ-misâk nipiy êkotê niwîh-ayân , itwêw . I shall stay by the Great Water,” he said.
êkoyikohk êskwâk âtayôhkêwin . This is the end of the sacred story.
